Posts.Content: Thank you for your comments, suggestions, and encouragement! I really appreciate them and hope your own journeys end well. Fairwind, I'm definitely heading back to UC-SF as soon as I get the results from my upcoming scans. My MO does not specialize in PC, and the time has come for more-focused expertise and heavier artillery! Re: Xtandi, my MO has mentioned it to me in the context of new, promising treatments but not as a next step. Something to consider, for sure. Unlike Zytiga, Xtandi wouldn't take away my meager remaining testosterone. Thanks again and I'll keep you posted.

Posts.Title: My Story

Posts.Content: Hello, everyone. This is my first post. Im happy to have found this forum and have enjoyed reading several threads, such as Fairwinds about the newest treatment options to consider (or not) after Lupron fails. I, too, will soon likely have to decide what to do next. But my path to that point is a little different than his. I was diagnosed at age 54 in April 2011. A physical produced a 5.6 PSA, my urologist found a palpable tumor, and I had a biopsy post haste. The pathology results showed a crapload of cancer, with 3+4, 4+3, and 4+4 scores in the right lobe and 3+4 in the left. I decided on brachytherapy and met with a highly respected radiation oncologist. Before I could ask him any questions, he said that an MRI Id had with my physical (for a different issue) showed some swollen lymph nodes in my chest. Hold everything, as PC metastases up there would render brachy moot. A subsequent CT scan revealed, and I quote, adenopathy throughout the retroperitoneum and in the retroesophageal and retroaortic regions of the posterior mediastinum. Oh, and an enlarged prostate (no sh*t, Sherlock!). In I went for a node biopsy to determine whether it was PC or something else, such as lymphoma. When the RO told us it was the former, my heart sank. Brachytherapy or surgery were no longer options, as the horse had already left the barn, so to speak. The lymph nodes were near my aorta, esophagus, venae cava, and other dicey places, so radiation was out, too. Hed treated 2,500 men for PC but had never seen it jump directly to lymph nodes in those areas. Mine is the Michael Phelps of prostate cancer, evidently. In the biggest fight of my life, I wasnt even going to get to throw any decent punches, really. My wife and I sat in our car in the parking lot and cried like babies. Worst time of our 33 years together, truly. A second opinion from UC-San Francisco confirmed the first and it was straight to Lupron, after a little Casodex appetizer. Fortunately, CT scans showed no bone or other metastases, and my PSA dropped quickly to <.05 and stayed in that neighborhood until December 2012, when it ticked up to .17. Six weeks later it was .30. Six weeks after that it was .99. Michael was swimming well! I went back on Casodex last April 2013, after which my next two 6-week PSAs were 1.33 (not bad, up 33%) and 2.29 (not good). My oncologist on Monday tripled my dose and ordered CT and bone scans that Ill get soon. Well see. He mentioned Provenge and Zytiga as potential next-steps if the megadose doesnt do the trick. As charming as my side effects from Lupron and Casodex are, Im not certain Im in the market for many more, especially if their cause extends my life by only four to six months. OTOH, my insurance company said theyd cover Provenge, somaybe it would be cool to have turbocharged lymphocytes! The common cold doesnt stand a chance, Im thinkin. One day at a time, right? Thanks for reading.

AgeInfo.Phrase: I was diagnosed at age 54 in April 2011 <Z> <Z>
